page.title: 08PENKRIDGE NATURE RESERVE
page.content: The reserve consists of two lowland wet meadows and lies approximately three miles west of Penkridge, near Whiston. The reserve is about two acres and comprises two meadows separated by a brook, and enclosed by another brook and trees. The Staffordshire Way footpath runs through the meadows, and The Penkridge Naturalists manage the reserve. The area is botanically rich with typical wetland plants, but has uncommon species such as orchids, fen bedstraw and little teasel. The cover provided by the reserve attracts interesting bird species such as woodcock, woodpeckers, owls, blackcap and grasshopper warblers. Butterflies are abundant during the summer months.
